contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox Athletic Conference |name = Dakota Athletic Conference |short_name = DAC |established = 2000 |dissolved = 2012 |logo = Dakota Athletic Conference logo.png |logo_size = 150 |association = [[National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics|NAIA]] |division = |subdivision = |members = 4 (final)<br>10 (all-time) |sports = 15 |mens = 8 |womens = 7 |region = [[The Dakotas]]<br>[[List of NAIA regions#Region III of the NAIA|Region III of the NAIA]] |former_names = |hq_city = Dickinson |hq_state = North Dakota |commissioner = |since = |website = [http://www.dakotaac.org dakotaac.org] |color = |font_color = |map = DAC-USA-states.PNG |map_size = 250 }} The '''Dakota Athletic Conference''' ('''DAC''') was a college athletic conference affiliated with the [[National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics|NAIA]]. As the name implies, member teams were located in the states of [[North Dakota]] and [[South Dakota]]. The conference folded in 2012. ==History== The Dakota Athletic Conference was formed from a merger between the [[North Dakota College Athletic Conference]] and the [[South Dakota Intercollegiate Conference]]. Ten schools were a part of the conference in its history: the [[University of Mary]] joined the [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]] in 2006, and [[Huron University|Si Tanka-Huron]] closed in 2005. [[Dakota State University]] announced they were leaving the DAC in July 2011 to become an NAIA independent.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dsuathletics.com/news/2010/080610-independent.aspx|title=DSU Athletics announces move to independent status|publisher=Dakota State University |accessdate=2011-01-01}}</ref> Additionally, member schools [[Minot State]], [[South Dakota School of Mines and Technology]], and [[Black Hills State University]] also left the conference while in the process of transitioning to [[NCAA Division II]]. This left the conference with four schools for 2011-12, after which [[Dickinson State University]] left for the [[Frontier Conference]] and [[Jamestown College]], [[Mayville State University]], and [[Valley City State University]] became [[NAIA independent schools]]. The DAC is one of the only NAIA conferences to have a television contract; [[America One]] owns the broadcast rights to the conference, although most of the games are only carried through the network's subscription service, B2 Networks. ==Past members== {| class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align: center;" !Institution !Nickname !Location !Founded !Type !Enrollment !Current<br>Conference |- |[[Black Hills State University]] |[[Black Hills State Yellow Jackets|Yellow Jackets]] |[[Spearfish, South Dakota]] |1881 |Public |4,739 |[[Rocky Mountain Athletic Conference|RMAC]]<br>(NCAA Division II) |- |[[Dakota State University]] |[[Dakota State Trojans|Trojans]] |[[Madison, South Dakota]] |1881 |Public |2,282 |[[NAIA independent schools|NAIA Independent]] |- |[[Dickinson State University]] |[[Dickinson State Blue Hawks|Blue Hawks]] |[[Dickinson, North Dakota]] |1916 |Public |2,572 |[[Frontier Conference]] |- |[[Jamestown College]] |[[Jamestown Dakota]] |1889 |Public |780 |[[NAIA independent schools|NAIA Independent]] |- |[[Minot State University]] |[[Minot State Beavers|Beavers]] |[[Minot, North Dakota]] |1913 |Public |3,851 |[[Northern Sun Intercollegiate Conference|NSIC]]<br>(NCAA Division II) |- |[[Huron University|Si Tanka University at Huron]] |[[Si Tanka Screaming Eagles|Screaming Eagles]] |[[Huron, South Dakota]] |1883 |Private |n/a |school closed in 2005 |- |[[South Dakota School of Mines and Technology]] |[[South Dakota Mines Hardrockers|Hardrockers]] |[[Rapid City, South Dakota]] |1885 |Public |2,345 |[[NCAA Division II independent schools|NCAA D-II Independent]] |- |[[University of Mary]] |[[Mary Marauders|Marauders]] |[[Bismarck, North Dakota]] |1959 |Private |2,758 |[[Northern Sun Intercollegiate Conference|NSIC]]<br>(NCAA Division II) |- |[[Valley City State University]] |[[Valley City State Vikings|Vikings]] |[[Valley City, North Dakota]] |1890 |Public |1,220 |[[NAIA independent schools|NAIA Independent]] |} ==Sports== Member schools fielded men's and women's teams in [[cross country running|cross country]], [[basketball]], [[track and field]] and [[golf]]. Men's-only sports were [[baseball]], [[American football|football]] and [[collegiate wrestling|wrestling]], while [[soccer]], [[softball]] and [[volleyball]] were only offered for women. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.dakotaac.org}} {{NAIA conference navbox}} [[Category:Defunct NAIA conferences]] [[Category:College sports in South Dakota]] [[Category:College sports in North Dakota]] [[Category:2000 establishments in the United States]]
